items.title: UK and Germany to build first direct offshore wind power link

featured_image.name: Offshore wind-powered interconnector 'black starts' grid ...

items.description:
Britain's National Grid and Germany's TenneT announced on Monday a partnership to develop an offshore wind interconnector in the North Sea, the first direct power link between wind farms in the two countries.

The announcement came as ten European nations gathered at the North Sea Summit in Hamburg, where they signed the Hamburg Declaration pledging to deliver 100 gigawatts of joint offshore wind projects by 2050 in a bid to reduce reliance on fossil fuels.

items.title: Webb telescope produces most detailed dark matter map ever

featured_image.name: James Webb creates the largest map of the deep Universe

items.description:
Astronomers have produced the highest-resolution map of dark matter ever created, using data from NASA's James Webb Space Telescope. The new map, published January 26 in Nature Astronomy, confirms with unprecedented clarity how dark matter's gravity shaped the structure of the cosmos by drawing normal matter toward it throughout billions of years of cosmic history.[1][2]

The research, led by scientists from Durham University in the United Kingdom and Northeastern University in the United States as part of the COSMOS-Web collaboration, analyzed Webb observations of a section of sky about 2.5 times larger than the full moon in the constellation Sextans.[3][1]

items.title: Microsoft launches Maia 200 AI chip to challenge Nvidia

featured_image.name: Prediction: This AI Chip Stock Will Outperform Nvidia Again in 2026

items.description:
Microsoft on Monday unveiled the Maia 200, its second-generation in-house artificial intelligence chip, marking an escalation in the growing competition among tech giants to reduce their reliance on Nvidia hardware.

The new accelerator comes online this week in a data center in Iowa, with plans for deployment at a second facility in Arizona, according to Reuters. Microsoft claims the chip, designed for AI inference workloads, delivers three times the FP4 performance of Amazon's third-generation Trainium processor and Alphabet's TPU offerings.[1][2][3]

items.title: Israel finds body of last Gaza hostage, clearing path for Rafah reopening

featured_image.name: Waiting for Ran Gvili | The Times of Israel

items.description:
The Israeli Defense Forces announced Monday that the body of Master Sgt. Ran Gvili, the last remaining Israeli hostage from the October 7, 2023 attacks, has been found and identified in a Gaza cemetery, bringing a 28-month ordeal to a close and clearing the path for a contentious reopening of the Rafah border crossing.

The recovery marks the end of a chapter that began when 251 people were taken captive during Hamas's attack on southern Israel. With Gvili's return, no Israeli hostages remain in the Gaza Strip for the first time in over two years.

items.title: Venezuela's acting president says she has had 'enough' US orders

featured_image.name: Venezuela vice president Delcy Rodriguez has been formally sworn in as  interim president.

items.description:
Venezuela's interim leader Delcy Rodríguez delivered a pointed rebuke to Washington on Sunday, declaring that she has had "enough" of orders from the United States as her government navigates the precarious aftermath of former President Nicolás Maduro's capture by American forces earlier this month.

"Enough orders from Washington on politicians in Venezuela. Let Venezuelan politics resolve our differences and internal conflicts. Enough of foreign powers," Rodríguez said in an address to oil workers at the Puerto La Cruz refinery in the eastern state of Anzoátegui, according to Xinhua and CNN. The speech, broadcast on state-run television, marked a notable shift in tone from the acting president who initially received backing from the Trump administration.[1][2][3]

items.title: Nearly 4 billion people face extreme heat by 2050, study finds

featured_image.name: Scientists call another near-record hot year a 'warning shot ... - NPR

items.description: Nearly 3.8 billion people worldwide could face extreme heat conditions by mid-century if global temperatures rise 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, according to new research from the University of Oxford published on Monday in the journal Nature Sustainability. The study arrives as separate findings reveal the Arctic has entered a "new era" of bioclimatic extremes, underscoring the accelerating pace of climate change across the planet's most diverse environments.

items.title: Gold surges past $5,000 for the first time as dollar weakens

featured_image.name: Gold blasts past $5,000 to record high on safe-haven rush

items.description:
Gold smashed through the $5,000 barrier for the first time on Monday, climbing to a record above $5,100 as investors piled into safe-haven assets amid a weaker dollar and mounting speculation that the United States and Japan may jointly intervene to prop up the yen.

Spot gold touched an all-time high of $5,110.50 per ounce, extending a historic rally that has seen the precious metal gain more than 17% in the first weeks of 2026, following a 64% surge last year — its biggest annual gain since 1979. Silver continued its parallel ascent, scaling new peaks above $109 an ounce after breaking $100 for the first time on Friday.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: EU approves ban on Russian gas imports by 2027

featured_image.name: EU agrees to ban all imports of Russian gas by fall 2027

items.description:
European Union countries on Monday gave final approval to a law banning Russian gas imports by late 2027, marking a decisive step in the bloc's effort to end its energy dependence on Moscow nearly four years after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

Under the approved legislation, the EU will halt Russian liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports by the end of 2026 and pipeline gas by September 30, 2027. The deadline may extend to November 1, 2027, if a member state struggles to fill its gas storage with non-Russian supplies ahead of winter.[1][2][3]

items.title: Synthesia raises $200M at $4B valuation, offers employee share cashout

featured_image.name: AI Video Startup Synthesia Valued At $4 Billion In $200 ...

items.description:
British AI video startup Synthesia has closed a $200 million Series E round that nearly doubles its valuation to $4 billion, while pioneering an unusual move for a European company: partnering with Nasdaq to let employees sell their shares without going public.

The funding round was led by existing investor GV, the venture arm of Alphabet, with participation from Nvidia's NVentures, Kleiner Perkins, Accel, New Enterprise Associates, PSP Growth, and Air Street Capital. New investors include Evantic, the venture firm founded by former Sequoia investors Matt Miller, and secretive VC firm Hedosophia.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: 10 European nations to sign pact for 100 GW of offshore wind

featured_image.name: Hamburg to host third North Sea Summit

items.description:
Britain, Germany, and eight other European nations are set to sign a clean energy pact on Monday committing to jointly develop 100 gigawatts of offshore wind power through cross-border projects in the North Sea, underscoring the region's resolve to pursue renewable energy despite recent criticism from U.S. President Donald Trump.

The agreement will be formalized at the North Sea Summit in Hamburg, hosted by German Chancellor Friedrich Merz. Participating countries include Britain, Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Iceland, Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and Norway.[1][2]

items.title: Scientists find 1,730 viruses in world's deepest blue hole

featured_image.name: Inside the world's deepest blue hole

items.description:
Chinese marine scientists have identified approximately 1,730 distinct viruses lurking in the oxygen-depleted depths of the world's deepest known underwater blue hole, revealing a hidden ecosystem teeming with microbial life forms largely unknown to science.

The discovery, conducted by researchers from the Chinese Academy of Sciences, centers on the Yongle Blue Hole, colloquially known as the "Dragon Hole," a massive marine sinkhole in the South China Sea that plunges nearly 1,000 feet into the ocean floor. The findings, detailed in research published in the journal Environmental Microbiome, indicate that approximately 77 percent of the viruses detected had never been recorded before and could not be matched to existing databases.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Platinum, silver, palladium hit record highs as metals rally

featured_image.name: Gold breaks new record on Greenland tariff threats - CNBC

items.description:
Platinum, silver, and palladium surged to fresh all-time highs on Sunday as a historic rally in precious metals continued unabated, driven by safe-haven demand amid geopolitical turmoil and expectations for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts.

According to Reuters via MarketScreener, spot platinum climbed more than 3% to reach $2,859.25 per ounce, while spot silver extended its gains to rise nearly 5% to $107.99 per ounce—its highest level ever. Palladium also rallied, rising 3% to $2,076.93 per ounce.[1][2][3][4]

The moves come as gold breached the $5,000 per ounce mark for the first time on Saturday, according to the BBC, capping a week in which precious metals posted extraordinary gains. Silver has now gained more than 40% since the start of 2026 after rallying 147% in 2025, Reuters reported.[5][6]

items.title: Canada has 'no intention' of China free trade deal, Carney says

featured_image.name: Canada Flexes on Global Stage With an Eye to Its Own Survival

items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney declared Sunday that Canada has "no intention" of pursuing a free trade agreement with China, pushing back against President Donald Trump's threat to impose 100 percent tariffs on all Canadian goods if Ottawa strikes a broader trade pact with Beijing.

"We have no intention of doing that with China or any other nonmarket economy," Carney told reporters in Ottawa, emphasizing that the recent agreement with Beijing merely addressed specific tariff disputes that emerged over the past two years.[1][2][3]

items.title: China's top general investigated over alleged nuclear leak to US

featured_image.name: Xi's Purge of China's Military Brings Its Top General Down

items.description:
China's highest-ranking general is accused of disclosing sensitive nuclear arsenal information to the United States, according to The Wall Street Journal, in what analysts are calling the most significant military purge in modern Chinese history.

General Zhang Youxia, 75, the senior vice chairman of the Central Military Commission and long considered one of Xi Jinping's closest military allies, was placed under investigation on Saturday for "serious violations of discipline and law," China's Defense Ministry announced. Liu Zhenli, the CMC's chief of staff who oversees combat planning, was also placed under investigation.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: WHO chief calls U.S. withdrawal reasons 'untrue,' says exit makes world 'less safe'

featured_image.name: WHO chief Tedros in quarantine after contact gets COVID-19 ...

items.description:
World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus on Saturday rejected the reasons cited by the United States for its formal withdrawal from the U.N. health agency, calling them "untrue" and warning that the exit "makes both the U.S. and the world less safe."[1][2][3]

The sharp rebuke came two days after Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. announced the completion of the withdrawal process in a joint statement, marking the first time since the WHO's founding in 1948 that the United States has not been a member.[4][5]

items.title: US envoys meet Netanyahu to discuss Gaza reconstruction plan

featured_image.name: Witkoff and Kushner meet Netanyahu as US seeks to advance ...

items.description:
An anti-Hamas militia operating under Israeli control has claimed responsibility for the assassination of a senior Hamas police chief in Gaza, as US special envoys arrived in Israel on Saturday to discuss the future of the war-torn territory with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

The targeted killing on January 12 by the Popular Forces militia reflects Israel's growing reliance on Palestinian armed groups to combat Hamas in areas it controls, even as the Trump administration pushes forward with its ambitious "Board of Peace" plan to rebuild Gaza.

items.title: Trump advisers meet Netanyahu to advance Gaza ceasefire talks

featured_image.name: Witkoff and Kushner meet Netanyahu as US seeks to advance ...

items.description:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declined a direct White House request for President Isaac Herzog to represent Israel at the inauguration of President Trump's Gaza Board of Peace in Davos, Switzerland, resulting in Israel's notable absence from Thursday's ceremony and exposing tensions between Jerusalem and Washington as Trump's peace initiative advances into its second phase.

The White House extended invitations to 58 nations to join the Board of Peace, with Netanyahu himself receiving an invitation, according to Axios. However, due to an arrest warrant issued by the International Criminal Court in 2024, Netanyahu could not travel to Switzerland. With Herzog already attending the World Economic Forum, senior U.S. officials twice approached the Prime Minister's Office on Tuesday and Wednesday, proposing that Herzog sit on stage alongside Arab and Muslim leaders and sign the board's charter, according to Israel's Channel 12.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: China places two top generals under investigation in major purge

featured_image.name: China's Xi Places His Top General Under Investigation as ...

items.description:
China's highest-level military purge in decades became official on January 24, 2026, when state media confirmed that Zhang Youxia, vice chairman of the Central Military Commission and a member of the ruling Politburo, has been placed under investigation for "serious violations of discipline and law." Liu Zhenli, chief of the Joint Staff Department and a CMC member, is also being investigated, according to an announcement from the Ministry of National Defense.[1][2][3]

The terse statement said the decision to open investigations into both senior military figures followed "deliberation by the Party's central leadership," providing no further details on the alleged violations.[4][5]

items.title: Gold crosses $5,000 per ounce for the first time

featured_image.name: Gold smashes new record of $4,600 as Powell probe and global flashpoints ignite safe-haven rush

items.description:
Gold prices have breached the closely watched $5,000-per-ounce barrier for the first time, capping a historic rally fueled by a weakening U.S. dollar, robust central bank buying, and expectations of further Federal Reserve rate cuts.

As of Saturday, January 24, 2026, spot gold traded at approximately $4,988 per ounce after establishing an intra-day record high above $5,009 earlier in the session. The precious metal has gained roughly 15% since the start of 2026 and nearly 80% compared to a year ago. Silver has been equally buoyant, with prices approaching $100 per ounce after hitting unprecedented highs in recent sessions.[1][2][3][4][5]

items.title: Trump threatens 100% tariffs if Canada proceeds with China deal

featured_image.name: Trump imposes promised tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump on Saturday threatened to impose a 100 percent tariff on all Canadian goods entering the United States if Canada proceeds with its newly signed trade agreement with China, dramatically escalating a week of diplomatic tensions with America's northern neighbor.

"If Governor Carney thinks he is going to make Canada a 'Drop Off Port' for China to send goods and products into the United States, he is sorely mistaken," Trump wrote on Truth Social, referring to Prime Minister Mark Carney. "China will eat Canada alive, completely devour it, including the destruction of their businesses, social fabric, and general way of life."[1][2]
